Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Situation2: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Story: As the family holiday drew near, my daughter called, her voice warm with anticipation. “Dad, don’t forget, we’re all counting on you to help bring everyone together this year. The kids miss you.” I promised I’d call my grandson that evening, maybe even set up a video chat so he could show me his latest drawing. But as I hung up, I glanced around the pool deck. A few chairs were out of place, not dangerous, but not up to standard either. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “We expect everything to be perfect, especially before the weekend rush.” I knew I should realign the chairs, check the bolts, make sure nothing would cause a problem. Yet, my phone buzzed again—a reminder to call my grandson before his bedtime. I felt the tug in both directions: the duty to my family, the responsibility to my job. My heart ached with the pressure, knowing that whichever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
